 20     # Isolates the whitespace-sensitive tags in the string and uses preserve
 21     # to convert any endlines inside them into HTML entities for endlines.
 22     def find_and_preserve(input)
 23       input = input.to_s
 24       input.scan(/<(textarea|code|pre)[^>]*>(.*?)<\/\1>/im) do |tag, contents|
 25         input = input.gsub(contents, preserve(contents))
 26       end
 27       input
 28     end
 29 
 30     # Takes any string, finds all the endlines and converts them to
 31     # HTML entities for endlines so they'll render correctly in
 32     # whitespace-sensitive tags without screwing up the indentation.
 33     def preserve(input)      
 34       input.gsub(/\n/, '&#x000A;').gsub(/\r/, '')
 35     end
 36 
 37     alias_method :flatten, :preserve

 39     # Takes an Enumerable object and a block
 40     # and iterates over the object,
 41     # yielding each element to a Haml block
 42     # and putting the result into <tt><li></tt> elements.
 43     # This creates a list of the results of the block.
 44     # For example:
 45     #
 46     #   = list_of([['hello'], ['yall']]) do |i|
 47     #     = i[0]
 48     #
 49     # Produces:
 50     #
 51     #   <li>hello</li>
 52     #   <li>yall</li>
 53     #
 54     # And
 55     #
 56     #   = list_of({:title => 'All the stuff', :description => 'A book about all the stuff.'}) do |key, val|
 57     #     %h3= key.humanize
 58     #     %p= val
 59     #
 60     # Produces:
 61     #
 62     #   <li>
 63     #     <h3>Title</h3>
 64     #     <p>All the stuff</p>
 65     #   </li>
 66     #   <li>
 67     #     <h3>Description</h3>
 68     #     <p>A book about all the stuff.</p>
 69     #   </li>
 70     #
 71     def list_of(array, &block) # :yields: item
 72       to_return = array.collect do |i|
 73         result = capture_haml(i, &block)
 74         
 75         if result.count("\n") > 1
 76           result.gsub!("\n", "\n  ")
 77           result = "\n  #{result.strip}\n"
 78         else
 79           result.strip!
 80         end
 81         
 82         "<li>#{result}</li>"
 83       end
 84       to_return.join("\n")
 85     end

 87     # Returns a hash containing default assignments for the xmlns and xml:lang
 88     # attributes of the <tt>html</tt> HTML element.
 89     # It also takes an optional argument for the value of xml:lang and lang,
 90     # which defaults to 'en-US'.
 91     # For example,
 92     #
 93     #   %html{html_attrs}
 94     #
 95     # becomes
 96     #
 97     #   <html xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' xml:lang='en-US' lang='en-US'>
 98     #
 99     def html_attrs(lang = 'en-US')
100       {:xmlns => "http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml", 'xml:lang' => lang, :lang => lang}
101     end

103     # Increments the number of tabs the buffer automatically adds
104     # to the lines of the template.
105     # For example:
106     #
107     #   %h1 foo
108     #   - tab_up
109     #   %p bar
110     #   - tab_down
111     #   %strong baz
112     #
113     # Produces:
114     #
115     #   <h1>foo</h1>
116     #     <p>bar</p>
117     #   <strong>baz</strong>
118     #
119     def tab_up(i = 1)
120       buffer.tabulation += i
121     end
122 
123     # Increments the number of tabs the buffer automatically adds
124     # to the lines of the template.
125     #
126     # See tab_up.
127     def tab_down(i = 1)
128       buffer.tabulation -= i
129     end

131     # Surrounds the given block of Haml code with the given characters,
132     # with no whitespace in between.
133     # For example:
134     #
135     #   = surround '(', ')' do
136     #     %a{:href => "food"} chicken
137     #
138     # Produces:
139     #
140     #   (<a href='food'>chicken</a>)
141     #
142     # and
143     #
144     #   = surround '*' do
145     #     %strong angry
146     #
147     # Produces:
148     #
149     #   *<strong>angry</strong>*
150     #
151     def surround(front, back = nil, &block)
152       back ||= front
153       output = capture_haml(&block)
154       
155       "#{front}#{output.chomp}#{back}\n"
156     end
157     
158     # Prepends the given character to the beginning of the Haml block,
159     # with no whitespace between.
160     # For example:
161     #
162     #   = precede '*' do
163     #     %span.small Not really
164     #
165     # Produces:
166     #
167     #   *<span class='small'>Not really</span>
168     #
169     def precede(char, &block)
170       "#{char}#{capture_haml(&block).chomp}\n"
171     end
172     
173     # Appends the given character to the end of the Haml block,
174     # with no whitespace between.
175     # For example:
176     #
177     #   click
178     #   = succeed '.' do
179     #     %a{:href=>"thing"} here
180     #
181     # Produces:
182     #
183     #   click
184     #   <a href='thing'>here</a>.
185     #
186     def succeed(char, &block)
187       "#{capture_haml(&block).chomp}#{char}\n"
188     end

190     # Captures the result of the given block of Haml code,
191     # gets rid of the excess indentation,
192     # and returns it as a string.
193     # For example, after the following,
194     #
195     #   .foo
196     #     - foo = capture_haml(13) do |a|
197     #       %p= a
198     #
199     # the local variable <tt>foo</tt> would be assigned to "<p>13</p>\n".
200     #
201     def capture_haml(*args, &block)
202       capture_haml_with_buffer(buffer.buffer, *args, &block)
203     end
204 
205     # Outputs text directly to the Haml buffer, with the proper tabulation
206     def puts(text = "")
207       buffer.buffer << ('  ' * buffer.tabulation) << text.to_s << "\n"
208       nil
209     end

211     #
212     # call-seq:
213     #   open(name, attributes = {}) {...}
214     #   open(name, text, attributes = {}) {...}
215     #
216     # Creates an HTML tag with the given name and optionally text and attributes.
217     # Can take a block that will be executed
218     # between when the opening and closing tags are output.
219     # If the block is a Haml block or outputs text using puts,
220     # the text will be properly indented.
221     # 
222     # For example,
223     #
224     #   open :table do
225     #     open :tr do
226     #       open :td, {:class => 'cell'} do
227     #         open :strong, "strong!"
228     #         puts "data"
229     #       end
230     #       open :td do
231     #         puts "more_data"
232     #       end
233     #     end
234     #   end
235     #
236     # outputs
237     #
238     #   <table>
239     #     <tr>
240     #       <td class='cell'>
241     #         <strong>
242     #           strong!
243     #         </strong>
244     #         data
245     #       </td>
246     #       <td>
247     #         more_data
248     #       </td>
249     #     </tr>
250     #   </table>
251     #
252     def open(name, attributes = {}, alt_atts = {}, &block)
253       text = nil
254       if attributes.is_a? String
255         text = attributes
256         attributes = alt_atts
257       end
258 
259       puts "<#{name}#{buffer.build_attributes(attributes)}>"
260       tab_up
261         # Print out either the text (using push_text) or call the block and add an endline
262         if text
263           puts(text)
264         elsif block
265           block.call
266         end
267       tab_down
268       puts "</#{name}>"
269       nil
270     end

279     # Gets a reference to the current Haml::Buffer object.
280     def buffer
281       @haml_stack[-1]

284     # Gives a proc the same local "_hamlout" and "_erbout" variables
285     # that the current template has.
286     def bind_proc(&proc)
287       _hamlout = buffer
288       _erbout = _hamlout.buffer
289       proc { |*args| proc.call(*args) }
290     end

292     # Performs the function of capture_haml, assuming <tt>local_buffer</tt>
293     # is where the output of block goes.
294     def capture_haml_with_buffer(local_buffer, *args, &block)
295       position = local_buffer.length
296       
297       block.call(*args)
298       
299       captured = local_buffer.slice!(position..-1)
300       
301       min_tabs = nil
302       captured.each do |line|
303         tabs = line.index(/[^ ]/)
304         min_tabs ||= tabs
305         min_tabs = min_tabs > tabs ? tabs : min_tabs
306       end
307       
308       result = captured.map do |line|
309         line[min_tabs..-1]
310       end
311       result.to_s
312     end

314     # Returns whether or not the current template is a Haml template.
315     # 
316     # This function, unlike other Haml::Helpers functions,
317     # also works in other ActionView templates,
318     # where it will always return false.
319     def is_haml?
320       @haml_stack ? @haml_stack.size > 0 : false
321     end
